verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, “Go, depart from here, you and the people whom you have brought up out of the land of Egypt, to the land I swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, saying, ‘I will give it to your offspring.’”
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew text, using 'offspring' for 'seed.'

verses.text: I will send an angel before you, and I will drive out the Canaanite, the Amorite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.
verses.comment: Stays close to word order; keeps the list from the Hebrew.

verses.text: Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not go up among you, lest I consume you on the way, for you are a stiff-necked people.”
verses.comment: 'Stiff-necked' is kept from the literal idiom, meaning stubborn.

verses.text: When the people heard this disastrous word, they mourned, and no one put on his ornaments.
verses.comment: 'Disastrous word' is a literal rendering; 'ornaments' refers to jewelry.

verses.text: For the LORD said to Moses, “Say to the people of Israel, ‘You are a stiff-necked people. If I were to go up among you for one moment, I would consume you. So now take off your ornaments, that I may know what to do with you.’”
verses.comment: Reflects the repetition and forcefulness of the Hebrew.

verses.text: Therefore the people of Israel took off their ornaments from Mount Horeb onward.
verses.comment: Follows ancient translations; 'Mount Horeb' is another name for Sinai.

verses.text: Now Moses used to take the tent and pitch it outside the camp, far off from the camp, and he called it the tent of meeting. And everyone who sought the LORD would go out to the tent of meeting, which was outside the camp.
verses.comment: 'Tent of meeting' is kept as a technical term for the place of revelation.

verses.text: Whenever Moses went out to the tent, all the people would rise up, and each would stand at his tent door and watch Moses until he had gone into the tent.
verses.comment: Literal rendering with clarification for readability.

verses.text: As Moses entered the tent, the pillar of cloud would descend and stand at the entrance of the tent, and the LORD would speak with Moses.
verses.comment: Keeps the order close to the Hebrew text.

verses.text: And when all the people saw the pillar of cloud standing at the entrance of the tent, all the people would rise up and worship, each at his tent door.
verses.comment: Repetitions highlighted as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So the LORD spoke to Moses face to face, as a man speaks to his friend. When Moses turned again into the camp, his assistant Joshua the son of Nun, a young man, would not depart from the tent.
verses.comment: 'Face to face' is a figure of speech for open communication, not literal sight.

verses.text: Moses said to the LORD, “See, you say to me, ‘Bring up this people,’ but you have not let me know whom you will send with me. Yet you have said, ‘I know you by name, and you have also found favor in my sight.’”
verses.comment: 'Favor' is the Hebrew hanan, often rendered as 'grace.'

verses.text: Now therefore, if I have found favor in your sight, please show me your ways, that I may know you and find favor in your sight. And consider too that this nation is your people.”
verses.comment: Stays close to Hebrew structure for emphasis.

verses.text: And he said, “My presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.”
verses.comment: God's reassurance; 'rest' includes safety and blessing.

verses.text: He said to him, “If your presence does not go with us, do not bring us up from here.”
verses.comment: Emphasizes Moses’ dependence on God's presence.

verses.text: For how will it be known that I have found favor in your sight, I and your people? Is it not by your going with us, so that we are distinct, I and your people, from every other people on the face of the earth?”
verses.comment: 'Distinct' is a literal rendering of Hebrew root.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, “This thing also that you have spoken I will do, for you have found favor in my sight, and I know you by name.”
verses.comment: God affirms His personal knowledge of and favor toward Moses.

verses.text: Moses said, “Please show me your glory.”
verses.comment: 'Glory' is a central theme; left literal.

verses.text: And he said, “I will make all my goodness pass before you, and will proclaim before you my name ‘The LORD.’ And I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious, and will show mercy on whom I will show mercy.”
verses.comment: 'Proclaim...The LORD' follows the Hebrew, referencing God’s covenant name.

verses.text: But he said, “You cannot see my face, for man shall not see me and live.”
verses.comment: Contrasts with 'face to face' in verse 11, showing different meanings.

verses.text: And the LORD said, “Behold, there is a place by me where you shall stand on the rock,
verses.comment: Maintains the concrete imagery of Hebrew.

verses.text: and while my glory passes by I will put you in a cleft of the rock, and I will cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
verses.comment: Phrase 'cleft of the rock' kept for accuracy.

verses.text: Then I will take away my hand, and you shall see my back, but my face shall not be seen.”
verses.comment: 'My back' and 'my face' are literal, expressing the limits of divine revelation.
